body_html: There's a work-around -- instead of server.join() have your parameter servers do sess.run(queue.dequeue) k times if there are k workers. Then each worker does an enqueue at the end of it's work. Here's a full example, search for create_done_queues here. An alternative solution was started in this pr -- #6185
body_text: There's a work-around -- instead of server.join() have your parameter servers do sess.run(queue.dequeue) k times if there are k workers. Then each worker does an enqueue at the end of it's work. Here's a full example, search for create_done_queues here. An alternative solution was started in this pr -- #6185
body: There's a work-around -- instead of `server.join()` have your parameter servers do `sess.run(queue.dequeue)` `k` times if there are `k` workers. Then each worker does an `enqueue` at the end of it's work. Here's a full example, search for `create_done_queues` [here]( https://gist.github.com/yaroslavvb/ea1b1bae0a75c4aae593df7eca72d9ca). An alternative solution was started in this pr -- https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/pull/6185
